name: 1. The Taj Mahal, Agra
info: Address: 64, Taj Road, Agra- 282001

name: 2. Varanasi- The Holy City of India
info: Varanasi has made significant contributions to India's History and is one of the oldest cities. It is one of the major pilgrimage sites for Hindus, and it has long associations with the sacred river Ganga. Hindu faiths are deeply associated with the place. Varanasi is known for its marvelous ghats and Kashinath Vishwanath Temple. People from the Hindu community believe that taking a bath in the sacred Ganga washes all away sins from their lives. Ghats, which are made on the bank of Ganga, add more beauty to it. Some of the largest ghats in Varanasi are Assi Ghat and Dasashvamedha Ghat. Later in the night, a grand Aarti is performed along with chanting of Hindu mantra by the priest that gives goosebumps to the people present at that time.

name: 3. The Golden Temple of Amritsar
info: Golden Temple is situated in the Amritsar, Punjab. A lake surrounds it with dazzling water. Some of the appealing features of the Golden temple are pleasant ambiance, 750 Kg of pure gold, and sanctified crystal clear water. It is a symbol of purity and harmony. Visiting the Golden temple will instill the values of calmness and unparalleled peace and will make you travel through ecstasy and mysterious holiness.

name: 4. Jaisalmer- The Golden City of India
info: It is a magnificent blend of old architecture that arises from the Thar Desert's dunes. It is named after the yellow sandstones that are used for the construction of most buildings and structures. Earlier, this city was treated as an outpost for strategic purposes, but now it is filled with magnificent gateways, Jaisalmer Fort, popularly known as Golden Fort, and splendid old mansions.

name: 5. The Red Fort, New Delhi
info: Nearest Metro Station: Chandini Chowk Metro Station (Yellow Line) and Lal Quila (Violet Line)

name: 6. The Gateway of India -Mumbai
info: Mumbai is a highly urbanized city and houses the headquarters of some of the largest multinational companies and banks. Mumbai is also called as Financial Capital of India and is Maharashtra's capital. The Gateway of India is 26 meters tall and stands in front of the Arabian Sea. It is a must-see structure whenever you visit Mumbai. It was built to commemorate the arrival of King George V and his wife, Queen Mary, in 1911. The magnificent structure was opened in 1924 with much celebration and grand fanfare. It is the tallest structure in the city. It is constructed with concrete and yellow basalt and Indo- Saracenic design.

name: 7. Mecca Masjid, Hyderabad
info: Address: Hyderabad, Telangana, 500002

name: 8. Amer Fort- Jaipur
info: Jaipur is Rajasthan's state capital. Amer, which is also sometime pronounce as Amber. Maharaja Man Singh I constructed a fortified palace called Amber in 1592, and it also facilitated as the capital of Jaipur. The palace is constructed on the high hillside, and you can reach up to the fort with footsteps or by shuttle rides that you can get from the town below. Some of the highlighting features of the fort are Jaleb Chowk. It was the first courtyard that had been decorated with elephants and consisted of Shila Devi Temple- The Goddess of the War.

name: 9. The Beaches of Goa
info: Goa is well known for its tourism and its associated beaches. It is a "go to" destination for the beach lover who wants to spend some quality time with their family and friends. Goa is situated along the western coastline of India and faces the mighty Arabian Sea. Goa has been explored by mainly overseas tourists. Goa houses the world's loveliest beaches, and each beach has its own charm and appeal.

name: 10. Wildlife Sanctuary and Periyar National Park, Madurai
info: Periyar National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary is South India's major tourist attraction, and the park is situated around a lake. British Engineers constructed it in 1895 with the purpose of providing water and irrigation to the beautiful city of Madurai.It was established in 1934, and the amazing park is home to more than 20 Bengal tigers, numerous species of mammals that includes wild boar, a large free-roaming Indian elephant population, the long-tailed macaque, and otters. Bird watching is a popular activity that happens in a park, and it includes continuous seeing of species such as kingfishers, storks, darters, hornbills, racket-tailed drongos, and also some good varieties of butterflies.

name: 11. Agra Fort
info: Address: Rakabganj, Agra, Uttar Pradesh, 282003

name: 12. The Ellora Caves - Aurangabad
info: It was constructed around the 5th and 10th centuries by the Hindu, Jain, and Buddhist Monk, and it is 300km away from Maharashtra's State capital Mumbai. UNESCO (United Nations body) considers Ellora Caves a World Heritage Site. Ellora Caves is a collection of chapels, 34 monasteries, and temples; it includes 17- Hindu, 12 of them Buddhist, and 5- Jain Temples. They are built nearer to each other, and it represents the religious tolerance that coexisted during that era of the Indian History of India. Buddhist Monastery Caves represent a number of shrines that features the beautiful Carpenter's Cave, believed to be one of the finest in India, and carvings of Buddha and the Saint.

name: How to Reach?
info: Jodhpur has a domestic airport that is only 5 kilometers from the city center. Other important cities including Delhi, Mumbai, Udaipur, and Jaipur are all well-connected via this airport. When you get to the airport, you can book a cab for roughly Rs. 100. Autos can be hired if you're seeking a cost-effective choice. The nearest international airport to Jodhpur is New Delhi's IGI airport, which is well connected to places all over the world.

name: List of Various Tourist Places In and Near Jodhpur
info: The Mehrangarh Fort rises perpendicular and impregnable from a height of 125 meters above Jodhpur's skyline. This old fort is one of India's most well-known, with a rich history and stories. The second gate of Mehrangarh Fort still exhibits the scars of cannonball raids by Jaipur's forces. The Moti Mahal, Phool Mahal, and Sheesh Mahal are famed for their magnificent latticed windows, carved panels, and artistically designed windows and walls.

name: 1. Mehrangarh Fort
info: The Mehrangarh Fort rises perpendicular and impregnable from a height of 125 meters above Jodhpur's skyline. This old fort is one of India's most well-known, with a rich history and stories. The second gate of Mehrangarh Fort still exhibits the scars of cannonball raids by Jaipur's forces. The Moti Mahal, Phool Mahal, and Sheesh Mahal are famed for their magnificent latticed windows, carved panels, and artistically designed windows and walls.

name: 2. Khejarla Fort
info: The 400-year-old Khejarla Fort is situated in a rural environment 85 kilometers from the major metropolis. Rajput architecture may be seen in the beautiful red sandstone structure, which is now a hotel. The fort's scenic settings, latticework friezes, and ornate Jharokas will captivate visitors.

name: 3. Umaid Bhawan Palace
info: Maharaja Umaid Singh erected Umaid Bhawan Palace in 1929 to combat a famine that had struck the state at the time. Because of the usage of stones from the Chittar hill, it was also known as the Chittar Palace while it was being built. HV Lanchester, a well-known British architect, designed the palace, which took 16 years to complete. The palace's architecture is a mix of Indo-Saracenic, Classical Revival, and Western Art Deco styles, built out of sandstone and marble. It is known as one of the world's largest private homes as well as one of the most stunning structures. It is the only palace constructed during the twentieth century.

name: 4. Moti Mahal
info: It is the Pearl Hall which was the place where the royal families of Jodhpur held their audience. The hall is noted for having glass windows and five nooks that allowed the queens to hear what was going on in the Sringar Chowki, Jodhpur's Royal Throne.

name: 5. Sheesh Mahal
info: The glass palace of Jodhpur, also known as Sheesh Mahal, is located within the Mehrangarh Fort compound. Mirror work runs from the ceilings to the ground, adorning the walls of this magnificent edifice. Overlaid on top of it is a mirror work with brightly painted religious figures made in plaster.

name: 6. Phool Mahal
info: The Phool Mahal, or Flower Hall, is the most extravagant of all the palace halls, as the name suggests. The Maharajas' pleasure dome is reported to be this lovely chamber. The gold used to build the Taj Mahal comes from Gujarat's Ahmedabad.

name: 7. Chamunda Mataji Temple
info: Rao Jodha's favorite deity, Chamunda Mataji, was brought to the Mehrangarh Fort as an idol. As a result, the fort was converted into a temple and used as a place of worship. Since then, the Chamunda Mata has been worshipped by the villagers. In reality, the goddess has remained the Maharajas' and royal family's Isht Devi (adopted goddess) to this day.

name: 8. Ranisar Padamsar
info: The Ranisar and Padmasar lakes, which are contiguous and located near the Fateh Pole in Mehrangarh, were built in 1459. Queen Jasmade Hadi, Rao Jodha's wife, ordered Ranisar Lake, while Queen Padmini of Rao Ganga, daughter of Rana Sanga of Mewar, ordered Padmasar Lake.

name: 9. Jodhpur Government Museum
info: Armory, textiles, local art and crafts, miniature paintings, ruler portraits, manuscripts, and representations of the Jain Tirthankaras are among the antiquities housed in the government museum in Umaid Garden. The nearby zoo is also a must-see for wildlife enthusiasts.

name: 10. Jaswant Thada
info: This milky white memorial, created as a tribute to the leader Jaswant Singh at the end of the 19th century, is a popular tourist destination. Jaswant Singh, the ruler of Jodhpur, put a lot of money into his domain. He attempted to reduce crime, apprehend dacoits, construct railways, and generally endeavour to improve Marwar's economy. The Mehrangarh Museum Trust (MMT) manages and maintains Jaswant Thada, which is open to the public. The Trust runs a museum in Jaswant Thada that features portraits of Marwar kings as well as educational didactics - the information acts as an orientation area for learning about Marwar's history through the portraits. At the time of music festivals such as the Rajasthan International Folk Festival and the World Sacred Spirit Festival, its grounds provide a tranquil setting for morning concerts.

name: 11. Ghanta Ghar
info: The Rajasthan clock tower, known as Ghanta Ghar, is constructed near the Sadar Bazaar, one of Jodhpur's busiest areas. Shri Sardar Singh Ji of Jodhpur designed and erected it. Tourists throng the Sadar Market's alleyways in search of Rajasthani textiles, clay sculptures, miniature camels and elephants, marble inlay work, and traditional silver jewelry.

name: 12. Mahamandir Temple
info: Mahamandir, which means "big temple," is a sacred site where peace reigns supreme. The temple, which is located on Mandore Road, is an architectural marvel. It is supported by 84 pillars and is embellished with intricate decorations and figures symbolizing various Yoga positions.

name: 13. Mandaleshwar Mahadev
info: Mandal Nath constructed the Mandaleshwar Mahadev in AD 923. It is thought to be one of the city's earliest shrines. Beautiful artwork of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati adorn the temple's walls.

name: 14. Sardar Samand Lake and Palace
info: The Sardar Samand Lake Palace, constructed on the banks of the Sardar Samand Lake by Maharaja Umaid Singh in 1933, is a magnificent hunting lodge. It is still the royal family's favorite getaway, with a large collection of African trophies and original watercolor paintings on display. The lake is a bird watcher's delight, attracting migratory and local birds like the yellow-legged green pigeon, Himalayan griffon, and Dalmatian pelican.

name: 15. Masuria Hills
info: Masuria Garden is one of Rajasthan's three most beautiful and well-known gardens. It is well-known among devotees because of a centuries-old temple dedicated to a local deity, Baba Ramdev, on top of the Masuria hill in Jodhpur's core. Here is a restaurant with a fantastic scenic view of the city.

name: 16. Shastri Circle
info: Shastri Circle is a traffic circle in the heart of Jodhpur. While it serves a use during the day, it is most impressive at night, when it is illuminated by lights and fountains. This attracts both locals and tourists to the area.

name: 17. Mandore
info: Mandore, the historical capital of Marwar, is located to the north of Jodhpur. The dewals or cenotaphs of Jodhpur's former kings can be found in this historically significant location. These cenotaphs, unlike the ancient chhatri-shaped cenotaphs that are distinctive of Rajasthani architecture, are modeled after Hindu temples.

name: 18. Kailana Lake
info: This small artificial lake, located on Jaisalmer road, is a great site for a picnic. It's like a romantic painting with a dash of color. The beauty of the lake lingers in your mind long after you've seen it. Boating facilities are also accessible through R.T.D.C. for individuals who want to go out on the lake.

name: 19. Machiya Safari Park
info: This park is roughly a kilometer from Kailana Lake on the road to Jaisalmer. It is home to deer, desert foxes, monitor lizards, blue bulls, hare, wild cats, mongoose, monkeys, and other creatures, including deer, desert foxes, monitor lizards, blue bulls, hare, wild cats, mongoose, and monkeys. The park also offers breathtaking sunset views that should not be missed.

name: 20. Somnath Temple
info: The Somnath temple, located in the heart of Pali city, is noted for its historical significance and sculptures. It was established in 1920 by Gujarat's King, Kumarpal Solanki, and is home to a number of minor temples dedicated to various gods and goddesses.

name: 21. Balsamand Lake
info: On the Jodhpur-Mandore Road, Balsamand Lake is around 5 kilometers from Jodhpur. It was constructed in 1159 AD as a water reservoir for Mandore. Later, as a vacation residence, the Balsamand Lake Palace was built on its beach. It is bordered by lovely green gardens with mango, papaya, pomegranate, guava, and plum tree groves. This area is also home to animals and birds such as the jackal and peacock. Tourists and locals alike flock to this lake for picnics.

name: 22. Guda Village
info: A vibrant spectrum of exotic fauna and nature can be seen at Guda, a Bishnoi settlement. Thousands of migratory birds use the area as a home. The Demoiselle crane is frequently seen frolicking in the lake. The pond is also home to antelopes and blackbucks. For nature enthusiasts, this is a must-see location.

name: 23. Chokhlao Bagh and International Center
info: Visit the Chokhelao Bagh, which is located at the foot of the Mehrangarh Fort. By planting and in-situ displaying excellent endemically historic flora of the Marwar region, the Mehrangarh Museum Trust has converted an over 200-year-old garden, complete with the fragrances, sounds, and textures of an eighteenth-century Marwar garden, into a Botanical Museum.

name: Help Others, Please Share
info: Splunk

name: 1. India Gate
info: This "Arc-de-Triomphe," like an archway, standing 42 meters tall in the center of Delhi, stands far higher in Indian hearts. It, formerly known as the All India War Memorial, was created to honor the 70,000 British Indian soldiers who died between 1914 - 21 in the First World War.

name: 2. Red Fort
info: The country's pride is Red Fort, also known as Lal Quila. It is a historic fort located in the city's older section. Over almost 200 years, Lal Quila was the Mughal Emperor's main home. The Mughals lived in Lal Quila from 1656 to 1856. Additionally, the historic structure served as the Mughals' political hub.

name: 3. Chandni Chowk
info: One of the long-lasting remains of the Mughal Period that Delhi still treasures is Chandni Chowk, often known as "Moonlight Square". In contrast, drawing tourists to the city, Chandni Chowk, one of the busiest and oldest markets in the nation, also attracts local businesspeople. The Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan's favorite daughter Jahan Ara Begum created and constructed Chandni Chowk around 1650 CE

name: 4. Humayun's Tomb
info: The Mughal Emperor Humayun's Tomb, also known as Humayun's Tomb, was constructed in Delhi in 1569-1570. His first wife and principal consort, Empress Bega Begum, ordered the building of Humayun's Tomb.

name: 5. Connaught Place
info: Connaught Place is one of the nation's biggest companies and financial hubs. The location, also called CP, is home to the corporate offices of some of the largest corporations. Additionally, it is a popular fashion destination. Connaught Place is home to the showrooms of some of the most well-known international brands.

name: 6. Qutub Minar
info: Qutab Minar, Qutb Minar, or Qutub Mina, You can spell it whatever you like. While spelling may have changed from one historian to the next, the building's attractiveness has stayed constant. Five floors make up this minaret's 73-meter height. It's interesting to note that the building's base diameter is 14.3 meters, but the diameter decreases to 2.7 meters as it increases

name: 7. Lajpat Nagar Marketr
info: Delhi is a shopper's paradise because of locations like Lajpat Nagar market. It is a residential and commercial area in Delhi's south. The location, which has the name of Lala Lajpat Rai, the Lion of India, is quite well-known in markets nationwide.

name: 8. Lotus Temple
info: One of the most well-known sights in Delhi is the Lotus Temple. The location is a Baha'i House of Worship and is distinguished by the shape of a lotus flower. The Lotus Temple was built for roughly $ 10 million and opened publicly in December 1986. The temple is well-known for simply more than its beauty.

name: 9. Purana Quila
info: A historic but beautiful structure known as Purana Quila or Old Fort stands amidst the glitz and splendor of Delhi city. Purana Quila is roughly two kilometers long and has a rectangular shape. According to history, the monument was constructed during the rule of Afghan Sher Shah Suri and Humayun.

name: 10. Akshardham Temple
info: Akshardham, or Swaminarayan Akshardham Temple, is one of Delhi's most significant social, religious, and cultural landmarks. BAPS did temple construction. Yogiji Maharaj served as its inspiration, and Pramukh Swami Maharaj produced it.

name: 11. Gurudwara Bangla Sahib
info: Regardless of religion, Gurudwara Bangla Sahib in Delhi should be on your travel itinerary. It is one of the most well-known Sikh Gurdwaras in both the city and the nation. The ninth Sikh Guru, Guru Har Krishan Singh, is reportedly tied to it.

name: 12. Lakshmi Narayan Temple
info: The Lakshmi Narayan Temple is a shrine to Lord Lakshmi Narayan and is more commonly called Birla Temple. When Lord Vishnu is with his consort Lakshmi, he is also known as Narayan, hence the name Lakshmi Narayan. Despite being a Hindu temple, it is accessible to individuals of all castes and beliefs.

name: 13. Hauz Khas Complex
info: The Hauz Khas Complex is a vintage charmer in Delhi's Hauz Khas neighborhood, a fascinating hub for young people. A mosque, a tomb, a water tank, an Islamic seminary, and pavilions make up the Hauz Khas Complex in the city's southern region. The Hauz Khas Complex provides a good feel of Delhi Sultanate rule during the thirteenth century.

name: 14. Dilli Haat
info: In contrast to a typical weekly market, Dilli Haat is a year-round marketplace. However, some vendors change positions in the market every two weeks. Rosewood and sandalwood sculptures, embroidered camel hide shoes, elegant cloth and draperies, gems, beads, brassware, metal crafts, and silk and wool fabrics are just a few of the distinctive goods you can find. The haat's exhibition hall often hosts shows to highlight its handicrafts and looms.

name: 15. Raj Ghat
info: The Raj Ghat is a pleasant, tranquil location in Delhi's older section. Mahatma Gandhi is honored at Raj Ghat. Raj Ghat is a riverside location on Mahatma Gandhi Road near the Yamuna. Politicians, dignitaries, and historians all highly recommend it.

name: Famous Local Food of Surat
info: Surat is well-known for its food offerings. The Gujarati thali is the finest served here, and the food diversity is vast. In the city's restaurants, you may eat for a reasonable price. Several cheap restaurants give a filling supper. Locha, a dish comprised of gram flour and boiled dal, is a local favourite.

name: How to Reach Surat
info: Tourists visiting Surat can take aircraft, trains, or buses because these tourist destinations are provided with a wide range of benefits.

name: Best Time to Visit Surat
info: Surat is best visited between October and March. Surat's weather is similar to that of other cities in India's western area. Summers in this area may be quite hot, reaching 40-45 degrees Celsius. The days might be unpleasant and inconvenient. In general, the nights are comfortable.

name: Best Time To Visit
info: If you're planning a trip to Chandigarh and want to know when the ideal time to go is, keep in mind that the city is located on the slopes of the Shivalik hills, which means it offers pleasant weather all year. The best times to visit are August through November when the weather is neither too cold nor too hot.

name: Food In Chandigarh
info: Chandigarh's cuisine is renowned for its excellent flavor and high-quality standards across the field. Their varied range of delightful foods provides a satisfying taste and texture. The eateries are generally well-decorated and have a clean environment. There are family eateries and venues to meet up with friends in Chandigarh. Some restaurants serve only lunch and dinner. If you're searching for something to eat in between meals, visit one of Chandigarh's snack stores.

name: Way To Reach Chandigarh
info: Chandigarh has its railway station, which is called Chandigarh. Aside from that, an international airport is well interconnected to domestic and foreign destinations. The city is also well interconnected to Northern India's major cities via road. Let's discuss all these three mediums to reach Chandigarh in brief.

name: 1. Barnawapara Wildlife Sanctuary
info: In Chhattisgarh, there are many great places to visit and enjoy on holidays, but Barnawapara Wildlife sanctuary is the best of all. It is located 100 Km from Raipur city, in the Mahasamund district, and from Mahasamund city, this wildlife sanctuary is approx. 45 Km far. This is one of the best tourist attractions in Chhattisgarh.

name: 2. Raipur
info: Raipur is the largest and most popular city in the Indian state of Chhattisgarh. Moreover, the capital city of Chhattisgarh is also Raipur. Mineral resources are found in abundance in Raipur, and due to this, this place is very famous for its steel and iron market. This city is very beautiful and one of India's cleanest cities. You will get to see many industries in Raipur, and because of this, this place is one of India's largest industrial centers. Here more than two hundred (200) steel mills, six (6) steel plants, one hundred ninety-five (195) iron plants, and many more industries or factories are available.

name: 3. Bhilai
info: Situated in the Durg district of Chhattisgarh, Bhilai is the second most popular and largest urban city after Raipur. It is believed that the name of this city is based on the Bhil tribe; this tribe stayed here for a very long time. This city is the most famous and popular because of Bhilai Steel Plant (SAIL) and for being an education hub. Apart from the Bhilai Steel Plant, Industry of Jaypee Cement, NSPCL Bhilai Power Plant, FSNL, Steel Authority of India, ACC Cement, Orient Cement, and many other companies are present here. Moreover, the nation's well-known institute, i.e., the Indian Institute of Technology Bhilai, is also in this city.

name: 4. Jagdalpur
info: Jagdalpur is located about 300 km south of Raipur, the capital city of Chhattisgarh. This city is located in the Bastar district and is one of the most popular and very beautiful cities in Chhattisgarh. If you are a nature lover and want to visit a place full of greenery, then this place is for you. There is everything that entertains, engages, and attracts tourists to this city. Here you find lakes, waterfalls, forests, and many other things that any tourist wants to visit.

name: 5. Mainpat, Chhattisgarh
info: Everyone likes to go to the hill station and dreams of enjoying their holiday. There are many popular and famous hill stations in India like Manali, Dharamshala, McLeod Ganj, and many more; tourists from far and wide come to these places and enjoy. Mainpat is also a hill station in the Surguja district of Chhattisgarh. This place is situated in the northeast of Raipur at approximately 360 km, and from Ambikapur, this place is approximately 55 Km. This place is extremely gorgeous but not so popular as another hill station.

name: 6. Madku Dweep
info: Island is the place where everyone wants to visit and enjoy. Madku Dweep is the most famous tourist destination in Chhattisgarh; people come from far-off places to enjoy here. This place is also known by other names such as Harihar Kshetra Kedar Dweep and Kedar Tirth.

name: 7. Sirpur
info: Sirpur is located in the Mahasamund district of Chhattisgarh. It is a small village located on the Mahanadi banks, and from Mahasamund, this place is approx 35 Km, and from the capital city Raipur this place is 78 km away. Sirpur is very famous due to its ancient temple, which is an archaeological wonder. Many Buddhist monasteries are found here, and the Buddhist monasteries here have great importance all over India.

name: 8. Chitrakote Falls
info: Waterfalls, rivers, and the sea are very nice to see. You can stare at them for hours, and they are perfect for refreshing and rejuvenating you. In Chhatisgarh, there are many waterfalls and rivers that attract tourists, and one of them is Chitrakote Falls. Chitrakote Falls is one of the most majestic places in Chattisgarh. Due to this, every day, thousands of tourists visit Chitrakote Falls. It is situated in the Bastar district; the distance of this place from Jagdalpur is approximately 38 kilometers to the west. On the tributary of the Godavari river, the Indravati River, this is a natural waterfall. This waterfall's height is approximately 29-30 meters, and the width is about 300 meters, which is 980 feet; because of its massive width, it is the widest waterfall in India.

name: 9. Kanger Ghati National Park
info: There are about 106 national parks in India, and one of them is Kanger Ghati National Park, also known as Kanger Valley National Park. This park is situated in the Bastar region near Jagdalpur. This park was declared a National Park by the Government of India in the year 1982. There are only a few densest national parks in India, and this is one of them. The biodiversity, underground geomorphologic limestone caves, landscape, and waterfalls are the beauty of this place.

name: 10. Chirmiri
info: Chirmiri, like Mainpat, is a lovely hill station in Chhattisgarh, situated in the Manendragarh- Chirmiri- Bharatpur district. It is known as the haven of Chhattisgarh because of its natural beauty. The mountains, rivers, and beautiful serene environment give a great experience to the tourists. Thus tourist spot is located on the banks of the Hasdeo River. Coal is found in abundance here, and because of this, this place is also known for coal extraction. Apart from the natural beauty, many ancient temples with spectacular architecture can be found here. If you enjoy traveling and seeing new locations, you must go to this location at least once. Some best places to visit in or near Chirmiri are:-

name: Conclusion
info: The state of Chhattisgarh is one of India's most beautiful. You will be able to view enormous natural beauty here. In this article, we mentioned some of the best places to visit in Chhattisgarh, but apart from these, there are many other tourist attractions also in Chhattisgarh. These include Achanakmar Wildlife Sanctuary, Guru Ghasidas National Park, Malhar, Bhoramdeo Temple, Ghatarani Waterfalls, Dantewada, Tirathgarh Falls, Indravati National Park, Dhamtari, Kanger Dhara Waterfall, and many more.

name: 1. Beyt Dwarka
info: Beyt Dwarka, a small island off the coast of Dwarka, is home to the namesake temple. Also it is said to have been Lord Krishna's residence when he came here. Guru Vallabhacharya is acknowledged for establishing the temple. Other temples in the complex honor deities like Hanuman, Vishnu, Shiva, Lakshmi Narayan, Jambavati, Devi, etc.

name: 2. Nageshwar Temple Jyotirlinga
info: This important Shiva temple is located between the city of Dwarka and the island of Beyt Dwarka on the Saurashtra coast of Gujarat. It is kept in the underground sanctuary by one of the world's 12 Swayamb (independent) Jyotirlinga. The main attraction of this calm and serene place is the vast garden with a pond and a 25-meter statue of Lord Shiva. Several archaeological excavations claim five early cities on the site. Nageshwar was believed to be known as "Darkavana", the ancient epic name of the Indian forest. The following are famous legends related to this mysterious temple.

name: 3. Dwarka Shardha Peetham
info: Adi Shankaracharya was a great saint, philosopher, and poet born in Kalladi, Kerala. He revived Hinduism and established the teachings of Advaita Vedanta. He wrote a narration of the Upanishads, other ancient scriptures and beautiful hymns.

name: 4. Rukmini Devi Temple
info: The Rukmini Devi Temple in Dwarka is one of the most important Dwarka tourist attractions. It is a place of worship dedicated entirely to Lord Krishna's spouse, Rukmani Devi. The place of worship is a work of art in itself. The Rukhmini Devi Temple is around 1.5 Km from the Dwarka city center and tells an old story of separation.

name: 5. The Dwarkadhish Temple
info: The Dwarkadhish Temple is a Hindu temple. It is an architectural masterpiece of limestone and sand for the 'King of Dwarka.' This gorgeous temple is one of the most significant religious places in the country, with 60 columns, a high spire with elaborate carvings, and magnificently carved entrances. The five-story tower of Dwarkadhish Temple is said to have been erected by Sambha, Lord Krishna's grandson. In Gujarat, the Dwarkadhish Mandir is one of India's most important temples dedicated to Lord Krishna.

name: 6. Bhadkeshwar Mahadev Temple
info: It is a Hindu temple in Bhadkeshwar, India. The Lord Shiva-dedicated Bhadkeshwar Mahadev Temple was erected about 5000 years ago. It is a temple that was built around a self-revealing Shivling that happened to be found in the Arabian Sea. During the monsoon season, the temple is submerged in the sea, and believers believe it is the natural way to perform the famous Shivalinga Abhisekam. Another attraction of this place that attracts tourists is its picturesque environment and lush greenery. The Bhadkeshwar Mahadev Temple is located near the circuit house at Sunset Point in Dwarka, Gujarat. The temple is open from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily.

name: 7. Shree Swaminarayan Mandir
info: Shree Swaminarayan Mandir is a famous Hindu temple in Dwarka.

name: 8. ISKCON Temple
info: Iskcon is an abbreviation for the International Society for Krishna Consciousness. This Hindu society is well-known for establishing Hindu temples throughout India and abroad. Since society is dedicated to Lord Krishna, it is also known as the Hare Krishna movement. The ISKCON Temple plays an immeasurable role in spreading the story and teachings of Lord Krishna. It's a global organization. The temples of Iskcon are scattered throughout the country, and one such temple is in Dwarka, which entices many tourists each year to Dwarka.

name: 9. Gomti Ghat Dwarka
info: Gomti Ghat is located at the mouth of the Gomti River, a tributary of the Holy Ganges, the most sacred river of Hindus. The river Gomti is said to descend straight from heaven. The Gomti Ghat is a popular tourist destination as it is a place where the powerful Gomti River joins the much more powerful Arabian Sea. It is a sacred bathing ghat on the banks of the Gomti River in Dwarka, Gujarat.

name: Conclusion
info: Dwarka is one of India's most beautiful tourist places. You will be able to view enormous natural beauty and rich history here. In this article, we mentioned some of the best places to visit in Dwarka, but apart from these, there are many other tourist attractions too.

name: 1. Gwalior Fort
info: It is considered one of the most formidable fortresses in northern and southern India and was dubbed "the jewel among the castles of India" by the Mughal emperor Babur. In Madhya Pradesh, central India, this monument is located atop a large rocky mountain overlooking the entire city of Gwalior. Evidence suggests that it dates back to the 6th century. A sculpture at the fort's summit represents the number 'zero', the second earliest reference to the number in history.

name: 2. Man Mandir Palace
info: A palace called Man Mandir Palace was built in the northeast corner of the fort between 1486 and 1516 by the Tomar monarch, Man Singh Tomar. The Palace was destroyed by time, although the ruins still exhibit the craftsmanship of the time.

name: 3. Jai Vilas Palace
info: King Edward VII, the then Prince of Wales, received this magnificent welcome for the first time in 1874 from Jayaji Rao Scindia, Maharaja of Gwalior. This palace is also known as the Jai Vilas Mahal, and it has been preserved in Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, to this day as a monument to Indian culture and splendor. Currently, it houses descendants of the Maratha Scindia dynasty. In addition to the 35 rooms of the palace, there is the Chitrangada Raje Art Gallery and a library with over 5,000 books.

name: 4. Teli ka Mandir
info: This temple, located in the Gwalior Fort, dates back to the 9th century and is the tallest skyscraper in Gwalior (100 ft.); before the British took over the Gwalior Fort, this shrine was used to refine oil.

name: 5. Saas Bahu Temple
info: The Saas-Bahu temple, built in the ninth century, attracts both visitors and believers. This temple was previously known as the Sahastrabahu Temple, after Lord Vishnu, who possesses numerous hands. It became known as Saas Bahu Temple as a result of increasing mispronunciation throughout time. Saas Bahu Temple does not represent Saas (mother-in-law) and bahu (daughter-in-law) but is a short version of Shastra Bahu, another name for Lord Vishnu.

name: 6. Sun Temple
info: The Surya Mandir, or Sun Temple, is a beautiful temple as well as an architectural marvel that graces Gwalior. Temple was built in 1988 by G.D. Birla and is dedicated to the holy Sun God. Built on the lines of the fabled Sun Temple of Konark, Orissa, it boasts stunning architecture constructed from red sandstone and pearly white marble.

name: 7. Tansen Memorial
info: Tansen was one of India's best musicians and an excellent vocalist in Akbar's courts during the medieval period. He was also one of the Mughal court's nine pearls. Tansen's music was said to have the power to generate magic, cause rain, and even captivate animals. Mohammad Ghaus, who taught him Hindustani classical music, was his teacher.

name: 8. Scindia Museum
info: This is one of Madhya Pradesh's most notable museums, dedicated to Jivaji Rao Scindia. This museum dates back to 1964 and occupies around 35 rooms at Jai Villas Palace. The museum is well-known for its manuscripts, sculptures, coins, paintings, and weapons collection. It is the best place to learn about Gwalior's history, particularly the Scindia dynasty. You will feel proud when you see the world's largest chandelier on display. The palace has Indian and British design elements, and it spans a huge area.

name: 9. Tigra Dam
info: Tigra Dam is located just outside the major city and offers a pleasant escape from the metropolis. Tigra Dam was built in 1916 on the Sank River, and since then, this freshwater reservoir has served as a primary water supply for city people to meet their daily water demands.

name: 10. Chhatris of Scindia Dynasty
info: Scindia Dynasty Chhatris are memorials created to remember and honor the Scindia Dynasty's monarchs. The first was built in 1817 CE in remembrance of Jayaji Rao Scindia. The architectural splendor of the attraction is well-known. Tourists must view the exquisite domes and gorgeous pavilions built of pink and yellow sandstone set among lush green meadows.

name: 11. Gopachal Parvat
info: Gopachal Parvat, located in the Gwalior Fort, is an excellent spot to see some ancient Jain imagery. The Tirthankaras may be observed meditating in seated or standing postures, making Gopachal Parvat one of Gwalior's numerous Jain sites. Gopachal Parvat is a significant and cherished place, particularly among Jain devotees.

name: 12. Gujari Mahal
info: The Gujari Mahal, built by Raja Man Singh for his favorite lady Mrignayani, is now a ruin and offers an archaeological museum that displays sculptures, statues, and other relics dating back to the first and second centuries BC. It is one of the best Mahals or Palace within Gwalior Fort and has been a tourist attraction for many years. It presently houses an archaeological museum with a diverse collection of artifacts from the first and second centuries linked to the Hindu and Jain faiths.

name: 13. Samadhi of Rani Laxmi Bai
info: An eight-meter-tall statue of Rani Laxmi Bai is built amid Phool Bagh to memorialize the well-known female fighter. In the 1857 battle against British authority, she revolted and fought to defend the princely kingdom of Jhansi.

name: 14. Gwalior Zoo
info: Gwalior is a vibrant city with a rich history, and the Gwalior Zoo is simply one more feather in its hat. The Gandhi Zoo (often called) was founded in 1922 by the royal dynasty Madho Rao Scindia and held several rare types of animals. It is a portion of a bigger park known as Phool Bagh. The range of wild species here includes golden peasants, sambhars, bison, hyenas, spotted deer, black bucks, and a white tiger. Many smaller populations of crocodiles, snakes, monkeys, and birds have also found a home at the zoo.

name: 15. Padavali and Bateshwar
info: Padavali is a citadel with several old temples located around 40 kilometers from the major town of Gwalior. In addition to the elaborate carvings, one of the temples has erotic engravings, earning it the nickname "Mini Khajuraho." From Gwalior, this is an excellent day trip to see Hindu architecture. The ASI discovered the temples in 2005 following excavation and the ongoing archaeological work. These temples' architecture is influenced by post-Gupta and early Gurjar-Pratihara traditions. Most of the temples are dedicated to Shiva or Vishnu.

name: 16. Tomb of Ghaus Mohammed
info: He was a brilliant counselor to King Babur and a music legend Tansen's instructor. The grave of a 16th-century prince-turned-Sufi is presently located in Hazira. This mausoleum features stunning Mughal architecture and has become a popular tourist destination. The majestic architecture of the mausoleum and the exquisite gravestone give this area a sense of quiet and tranquillity.

name: 17. Gurudwara Data Bandi Chhod
info: The Gurdwara Data Bandi Chhod was built to pay homage to Guru Har Gobind Saheb, the 52 imprisoned monarchs, and his eventual release from the Gwalior Fort. The Gurudwara is extremely religiously significant and is frequented by followers to honor the great guru.

name: 18. Sarod Ghar
info: Sarod Ghar is one of the top tourist attractions in Gwalior for music enthusiasts. This museum, also known as Kala Vithika, is unique. This location is in Ustad Hafiz Ali Khan's ancestral home and houses historic musical instruments utilized by notable performers. If you wish to learn about Indian classical music, you should visit this well-known museum in Gwalior. You may also look at vintage photographs of musicians and documents.

name: 19. Mitawali, and Padavali
info: The ancient sites of Mitawali and Padhavali are two attractions you should not miss when visiting Gwalior. Visiting these locations is a terrific way to learn about lesser-known parts of Madhya Pradesh's legacy while adding some fascinating photos to your Madhya Pradesh collection.

name: 20. Sarafa Bazar
info: No amount of contemporary shopping malls can take away the allure of traditional bazaars. Sarafa Bazaar's prominence in Gwalior demonstrates this. Sarafa Bazar, one of the fascinating sites to visit in Gwalior, is the ultimate habitat of shopaholics, offering a limitless variety of jewelry, textiles, handicrafts, and much more.

name: 1. Triveni Sangam in Allahabad
info: Triveni Sangam, the meeting point of three of Hinduism's most important rivers, is a holy site in Allahabad. The Sangam is the confluence of the Ganges, Yamuna, and Saraswati rivers. Because of the region's prominence, Allahabad is frequently referred to as Sangam. It is one of Allahabad's most popular and sacred tourist destinations, and it often organizes some of the religion's most important festivals and celebrations. Every 12 years, a very important celebration known as Kumbh Mela is celebrated here, and every six years, Ardh Kumbh is conducted here. Both these festivities feature big numbers of visitors and residents. Hindus wash where two rivers meet because it is thought that touching holy water takes away the sins of all births. If you go boating in the flowing waters of the Ganga and Yamuna, you will notice a variation in the colors of the water.

name: 2. Kumbh Mela in Allahabad
info: The Kumbh Mela, often recognized as the world's biggest pilgrim gathering, is a major moment in Hinduism. Many Hindus attend the fair to take a dip in the sacred waters. Bathing in the Kumbh Mela is supposed to bring sanctity to life by purifying it of sins. In rotation, the Kumbh Mela is conducted every three years at Haridwar, Prayagraj, Nashik, and Ujjain in rotation, thus once every twelve years. The Allahabad Kumbh Mela is conducted at Prayag, the Triveni Sangam, the confluence of the three sacred rivers Ganga, Yamuna, and Saraswati. The Ardh Kumbh Mela is conducted every six years at Haridwar and Allahabad.

name: 3. Anand Bhavan in Allahabad
info: Anand Bhavan, the old Nehru family mansion, has been transformed into a museum displaying numerous relics and items from India's independence campaign. When the previous Swaraj Bhawan of Nehru's family became the office of the Indian National Congress, Motilal Nehru planned a new Nehru house. Motilal Nehru personally designed the two-story haveli. The property was tastefully adorned with imported Chinese and European timber furnishings. The haveli is historically notable not just for its architecture but also for its crucial part in Indian history. Indira Gandhi offered Anand Bhavan to the Government of India in 1970 to be converted into a National Museum to preserve the Nehru family's history.

name: 4. Fort in Allahabad
info: During the time of Mughal Emperor Akbar, the Allahabad Fort was erected in 1583. This beautiful structure may be seen on the banks of the rivers Ganga and Yamuna in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. The Allahabad Fort is Akbar's most powerful structure. Because of its historical significance and the beauty of its architecture, this well-known site attracts thousands of tourists worldwide. The Prayagraj Fort, on the other hand, is off-limits to the general public. This fort is not accessible to the general population. Tourists may only visit there once every 12 years during the Kumbh Mela. The fort is also famous for its Akshayavat Vriksha (Banyan tree), which, according to mythology, was used by locals to commit suicide to achieve salvation. Those who want to visit the Akshayavat tree must enter through a tiny gate just in the region where the majestic tree is located. The fort also houses the Patalpuri shrine, which is supposed to have all of hell's gates.

name: 5. All Saints Cathedral Church in Allahabad
info: When you get to All Saints Cathedral Church through MG Marg via the streets of Prayagraj, you may believe that you are staying here for a few days. All Saints Cathedral, built around the nineteenth century, is one of the top attractions to see and visit in Prayagraj. This church is claimed to be designed in the Gothic style. It is a picnic destination for Prayagraj locals and a Christian religious site. Aside from these four locations, you may also visit the Public Library, Khusro Bagh, Planetarium, and Anand Bhawan with family, friends, or alone.

name: 6. Jawahar Planetarium in Allahabad
info: Jawahar Planetarium, established in 1979 next to Anand Bhawan, is the perfect blend of science and history. Every year, the planetarium offers a magnificent event called the Jawaharlal Nehru Memorial Lecture and many shows connected to the solar system and space for the attendees. You may learn about the movement of planets by participating in any of the shows or attending special fairs and talks conducted here on occasion. Spend some time at the planetarium while in Allahabad.

name: 7. Hanuman Niketan in Allahabad
info: On the way from Subhash Square to Mahatma Gandhi Road, Hanuman Niketan is also known as Safed Hanuman. Inside this temple, the temple's pride is a statue of ten Shivlings. The day of Mahashivratri is a unique time to visit since there is a large audience to witness the temple's major feature.

name: 8. New Yamuna Bridge in Allahabad
info: The newly built cable-stayed New Yamuna Bridge over the Yamuna River was finished in 2004 to relieve traffic congestion on Allahabad's Old Naini Bridge. The Naini Bridge is another name for it. It goes from northern to southern Allahabad, joining it in the Naina neighborhood. The bridge spans 1510 meters and is supported by cables to the deck.

name: 9. Alopi Devi Mandir in Allahabad
info: Alopi Devi Mandir is an unusual Hindu temple in Alopibagh, Allahabad, near the famous Sangam (confluence of the Ganga, Yamuna, and Saraswati). The Alopi Devi Mandir does not have a presiding goddess but a wooden vehicle called a doliê, usually adorned by Lord Shiva worshippers. The Alopi Devi Mandir is one of the country's Shakti Peethas, housing the last of Goddess Sati's bodily parts. During the Hindu celebration of Navratri, this sacred location draws large crowds of pilgrims. Tuesdays are very crowded at this temple.

name: 10. Mankameshwar Temple in Allahabad
info: Mankameshwar Temple, located on the banks of the Yamuna near Saraswati Ghat in Allahabad, is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple, which is enshrined by the shiva linga in the shape of Shiva, attracts hundreds of pilgrims, especially on Mondays, when the 'Shiva Pooja' is performed. The temple is very beautiful during Navratri. However, it may be extremely busy. Every Saturday, the Pradusha Pooja is performed. You might also bring milk and flowers to donate to the deity here.

name: 11. Patalpuri or Akshaypat Temple in Allahabad
info: Prayag has several temples as it is a pilgrimage site. Among these, the Patalpuri or Akshaypat temple is well-known. This temple was constructed near Triveni. There is a means to get there through a fort gate. Pillars support this temple's roof. Many Hindu deities' idols may be found here. Walking through the temple gives the impression that you are in a basement or tunnel. Perhaps this is why it is known as the 'Patalpuri Temple.' Dharmaraja, Annapurna, Vishnu, Lakshmi, Kuber, Shankar, Saraswati, and other deities have 46 idols. Some of these sculptures are rather lovely. Durvasa, Markandeya, and Vedavyasa are examples of sages.

name: 12. Company Garden in Allahabad
info: Shaheed Chandrashekhar Azad Park is known as Company Park, is where rebel Chandrashekhar Azad shot himself rather than submit to the firangis. This park is located close to Civil Lines Chowk. Company Park is Allahabad's largest park. During British time, it was the site of many British events. In one part of the park, a statue of Chandrashekhar Azad has been built. In addition, a small lake has been created in the park. It is also suitable for boating.

name: 13. Khusro Bagh in Allahabad
info: Khusro Bagh is a vast walled garden and tomb complex in Prayagraj (previously known as Allahabad), India, near the Allahabad Junction railway station. It covers forty acres and is fashioned like a quadrangle. It is famous for the three tombs of Jahangir's family:

name: 14. Minto Park in Allahabad
info: Minto Park, located on the banks of the Yamuna River in Allahabad, was once known as Madan Mohan Malviya Park. The four lion statues in white stone, created by the Earl of Minto in 1910, are featured here. Although it is a considerably smaller park, it has lush foliage and sitting amenities. There are also a few tea cafes in the park's area. Minto Park is where India was designated a colony from the East India Company to the British. In 1858, Earl Canning delivered Queen Victoria's Proclamation on the subject.

name: 17. Akshaya Vat in Allahabad
info: Akshaya Vat or Akshayvat is a historic fig tree located within the Allahabad Fort complex at Patalpuri Temple. This hallowed place is only available to the public for a single day during the Kumbh Mela celebration. After 2011, visitors to this tree must obtain permission from the Commandant of Allahabad Fort's Ordnance Depot. The history of this sacred and eternal tree is intertwined with Hindu mythology. Lord Narayana is said to have drowned the entire world for a brief while when the sage Markandaya asked him to demonstrate his almighty prowess. Only the Akshayavat Tree stayed afloat during the deluge. As a result, it is said to be the permanent and sacred banyan tree.

name: 18. Katra Market in Allahabad
info: There are several shopping opportunities in Allahabad, but Katra Market is a well-known market. If you wish to bring some Allahabad items with you as a memory of your visit, this is the most well-known market in the city.

name: How to Reach Allahabad
info: By Flight:

name: Local Food of Allahabad
info: In the Loknath Chowk neighborhood, a very tiny and busy lane is highly famous among street food eaters. Here you will find everything from chaat to kachori, lassi to halwa. The Hari Namkeen store, noted for its distinctive samosas, is one of the most popular. Awadh cuisine is accessible in addition to Mughal cuisine. Eat on Masala, popular for its biryani, kebabs, and kachoris and jalebis served with desi ghee, is one of the most well-known restaurants. Gari ki Ice may be found at Heera Confectionery as an after-meal treat. Eat On is one of Allahabad's most popular restaurants. The restaurant is well-known for its kebabs and delicious biryani.

name: Best Time to Visit Allahabad
info: Allahabad is best visited between October and March. Magh Mela is held from mid-January to early March (according to the Hindu calendar), and hundreds of people go to the city to bathe in the sacred Sangam. However, Maha Kumbh occurs just once every 12 months in the same month. Although Allahabad is an excellent site for travelers to visit all year because it is a holy city, there is always a joyous, celebratory mood. However, traveling here in the summer might be excruciating. During the monsoon, the ghats are unusable, and bathing in the river is prohibited. As a result, this time is likewise not ideal.

name: 1. Adalaj Stepwell:
info: Stepwells were created in the Western semi-arid regions of India during the 15th and 16th centuries to withstand seasonal changes and continue agriculture all year. The Adalaj Stepwell is historically significant because of its history and architecture.

name: 2. Baps Akshardham Temple:
info: Baps Akshardham Temple is a famous tourist destination in Gandhinagar. The Akshardham temple, completed in 1992, is devoted only to Bhagwan Swaminarayan and Hinduism's different avatars and saints. The temple mainly provides a place of prayer for devotees and a lovely and tranquil environment for cultural and spiritual interaction for visitors. The temple is known for having 200 Hindu gods and goddesses sculptures and a gorgeous traditional construction considered one of the region's best examples of fine craftsmanship. The temple's serenity, beauty, and significance are enhanced by finely carved pillars and Vedic writings on the walls.

name: 3. Indroda Nature Park:
info: One of Gandhinagar's most beautiful destinations is Indroda Nature Park. This place, also known as India's Jurassic Park, is popular with tourists, especially young people. The park also has a zoo, a theater, and event halls where serious research may be conducted. Indroda Park is India's first dinosaur park, complete with a museum and fossils and the dinosaur museum is the park's most popular attraction. The magnificence of the park's animals and plants will attract nature lovers. This prime place for a family picnic or a short venture into the forest.

name: 4. Sarita Udhyan:
info: This is a favorite tourist destination in Gandhinagar. This park, popular for picnics, is a great place to shoot wildlife. The park, positioned along the Gandhinagar river, is home to many peacocks and other migrating birds. The lush green fields, along with the birds singing, give a relaxing environment away from the city's busy life. You may also visit the park as part of a tourist excursion to unwind after a long day. It will take a couple of hours to see everything there is to see in the park.

name: 5. Dandi Kutir (Salt Mount) Museum:
info: This museum tells the story of Mahatma Gandhi's battle in the Indian independence movement and is culturally important. This monument symbolizes Gandhi's war against casteism and British colonialism. The museum recalls Gandhi's engagement in the Freedom Struggle, particularly his role in organizing the Dandi march against the imposition of salt restrictions on Indians, through detailed and stunning photos. The Dandi March was a major moment in colonial India's history, and the museum has a complete explanation. In addition, the museum has various artworks, memoirs, and artifacts of Gandhiji that he utilized throughout his campaign for independence. Salt Mount is located in Sector 13C of Gandhinagar.

name: 6. Puneet Van:
info: One of the park's unique features is the garden's structure, which is based on Hindu mythology's multiple zodiac signs. This Gandhinagar park, originally opened in 2005, is a park for around 3500 different plant species.

name: 7. Trimandir:
info: In Gandhinagar, there is a completely secular temple. This temple is unique, extraordinary, and one of the most significant destinations to visit in Gandhinagar because of its unique combination of Jainism, Vaishnavism, and Shaivism. The temple is split into several parts, each with idols and various Mahavira, Shiva, and Vishnu avatars. It encourages people to practice austerity and forego luxuries.

name: 8. Kishan Bhavan Fountain:
info: Kishan Bhavan Fountain is one of the most unique and attractive tourist attractions in Gandhinagar. Even though it appears to be a simple fountain, this location has become one of Gandhinagar's most famous tourist destinations.

name: 9. Funworld Dholakuva:
info: Funworld Dholakuva is a famous tourist attraction that focuses mostly on children. There are many other water rides in the park and boats. Water slides and a boat ride are kid-friendly, and there are a few rides for parents.

name: 10. Laser Show:
info: Akshardham: Hindu worshipers go to Akshardham, a famous temple in Gandhinagar. A fascinating performance broadcast on a large screen is one of the biggest tourist attractions near Akshardham temple. Apart from being a holy place, this temple also presents popular laser performances.

name: 11. Santsarovar:
info: Santsarovar dam was built on the Sabarmati River, and it's a lovely spot for a picnic with friends and family. Because of the wonderful atmosphere and surroundings, it is an ideal location for a relaxing evening stroll. The dam provides an exciting picture of the river rushing with all its might during the monsoon season.

name: 12. Vithalbhai Patel Bhawan:
info: In Gandhinagar, notable for its architecture, this structure carries a political significance. This is the structure that holds Gujarat's legislative assembly. As a result, specific permissions are required to enter the building.

name: 13. Deer Park:
info: To enjoy the environment and wildlife, you should visit Gandhinagar's Deer Park. The park provides a free breeding area for these shy animals while keeping them in their natural habitat.

name: 14. Swarnim Park:
info: A statue of Sardar Vallabhai Patel is the park's major attraction. A variety of little wildlife, including rabbits, squirrels, and butterflies, live permanently. Other than that, there are morning and evening jogging tracks, beautiful natural grasses, and a children's playground in the park.

name: 15. Botanical Garden:
info: The botanical garden in Gandhinagar is one of the city's most famous tourist destinations. Butterflies, glow worms, and stick insects are just a few creatures that thrive in the Botanical garden. This garden is known for preserving a wide range of rare species of plants from all around the country. On the one side, you'd see orchards, but you'd also see medicinal plants.

name: 1. Tyavarekoppa Tiger and Lion Safari
info: It is referred to as an "open zoo" since tigers and lions are allowed to roam freely in its interior. The location, which spans a sizable 200 hectares, is well-known for its 1998-launched Lion and Tiger Safari. In addition to safaris, the area is home to several wildlife species, including sloth bears, deer, and leopards. There is also a zoo and a playground nearby.

name: 2. Mandagadde Bird Sanctuary
info: If you skip this lovely bird sanctuary, your tour of Shimoga's attractions may remain incomplete. It is a tiny, charming island in the river Tunga that is about 32 kilometres from Shimoga town on the route to Thirthahalli. This is the greatest area to discover in Shimoga if you enjoy exploring peaceful environments.

name: 3. Gajanur Dam
info: Small village Gajanur is well known for its variety of birds. Visitors can also take advantage of an elephant training camp nearby. The environment, which has plantations and beautiful forests encircling the huge dam, is what makes it a well-liked tourist destination. There will be several photographic possibilities for this. It is situated 12 kilometres from Shimoga on the Thirthahalli road.

name: 4. Hosahalli
info: The town of Hosahalli, together with its neighboring village Mattur, is known throughout the world as the only site where the old Sanskrit language is being spoken on a daily basis and is also the official language. It is a special village that blends ancient India with modern civilization. It is located 4 km from the city of Shimoga on the Tunga River's banks.

name: 5. Sakrebailu Elephant Camp
info: Plan a trip to Sakrebailu Elephant Camp if you're travelling to Shimoga with children and family; it's one of the must-see attractions nearby. One can observe elephant herds being taught at Sakrebayalu Elephant Camp. It is a well-liked tourist destination and is located about 14 kilometres from the main town of Shimoga. Elephants at this eco-tourism facility are handled by knowledgeable mahouts. As they wash in the backwaters, engage with their young, and go about their daily lives, the wild elephants can be observed in their natural habitat.

name: 6. Keladi
info: The Shimoga District's Keladi village is renowned for its illustrious history and culture. The Keladi Rameshwara Temple and the Keladi Museum may be found in this prime location, which once served as the Keladi Nayaka Kingdom's initial capital. Keladi, a popular tourist destination in Shimoga, is an absolute haven for those who value serenity and spirituality. The Hoysala, Dravidian, and Kadamba architectural traditions are best represented by the temple dedicated to Lord Rameshwara.

name: 7. Shivappa Nayaka Palace Museum
info: On the banks of the river Tunga, which was created in the sixteenth century, is where this well-liked attraction is situated. The palace was created under the direction of Shivappa Naik and it is designed with rosewood that's why it is ranked among the top sites to see in Shimoga.

name: 8. Ikkeri
info: Ikkeri is a tiny historical location in the Sagar Taluk, around 3 kilometres from Shimoga Town. The Aghoreshwara Temple, which was built by the Keladinayakas, is Ikkeri's principal draw. The Lord Shiva-dedicated temple is surrounded by a sizable open area. The temple, which is on a somewhat higher height, has a modest but magnificent granite cubical through which one can enter. Due to its crystalline quality, the picture of the bull-headed Nandi at the temple's entryway is what draws attention. The beautiful carvings on the temple's environs show off the talent of former masters.

name: 9. Heggodu
info: Heggodu is a spotless village and one of those popular tourist destinations in Shimoga that has a small mystery. It is situated in Sagar Taluk. It is one of the few places that can count on NINASAM. NINASAM is an abbreviation for Sri Nilakanteshwara Natyaseva Samgha. It is a renowned theatrical institute and organisation committed to the advancement of the arts and culture.

name: 10. Kundadri
info: The charming residence of Kundadri Hill, a solid rock building with a Jain Temple at the top, is located in the Theerthahalli Taluka of Shimoga area. The Kundadri Hills are a cool location that is ideal to explore in any weather because they rise 3,200 feet above sea level. This walk to Kundadri, which is protected by lush green forests, is a lovely experience. It is also a sacred site for Jains and a great area for adventure seekers to do a little hiking and trekking. The Kundakundacharya Jain priest is credited with performing a significant penance on these hills, which bear his name.

name: 11. Achakanya Falls
info: One of Karnataka's lesser-known natural wonders is the Achakanya waterfall. In the Shimoga district of Karnataka, the waterfall is close to the village of Aralasurali, which is located around 10 km from Thirthahalli. The River Sharavathi creates the waterfall when it makes a spectacular leap through the thick Western Ghats woods. The breathtaking fall is between 6 and 7 feet tall. A sight to behold is the little yet majestic Achakanya Falls.

name: 12. Hidlumane Falls
info: In the Karnataka district of Shimoga, there are 6-7 mesmerising waterfalls collectively known as Hidlumane Falls. It may be found deep in the Mookambika jungles. These waterfalls are all hidden from the sight of one another, with the most beautiful one being the last in the series and located at the top. Due to the shallowness of the pool, many guests can be seen swimming there. However, swimming is not allowed here during the monsoon season because of the choppy currents.

name: 13. Shopping
info: Shimoga, a well-known tourist location in Karnataka, has a wealth of goods to offer its shoppers. The region is renowned for its handicrafts, rosewood and sandalwood carvings, sarees decorated with Kasuti art, and wooden toys covered in lacquer. The market is filled with a broad selection of garments of different fabrics varying from silk to chiffon and jewels.

name: 14. Gandhi Park
info: The city's inhabitants frequently use the Mahatma Gandhi Park. The park's swimming pool is its most prominent feature, and children can take swimming lessons while attending government-sponsored summer programmes. The Mahatma Gandhi Park's jogger's route is a great place for early-morning strolls and jogs because of the rich greenery that surrounds it. Each child will be drawn to one of the many various games in the kids' play area. The park has a miniature railway that travels through it, and there are several lovely pieces of art on display.

name: 15. Tripurantaka Temple
info: One of the most notable temples is the Tripurantaka or Tripurantakesvara temple, located in the Karnataka state town of Balligave in the Shivamogga district. During the reign of King Vishnuvardhana, the Western Chalukyas constructed the temple. It was built somewhere around 1070 AD. An ancient temple called Tripurantaka is located to the northeast of Balligave. Western or Later Chalukyas constructed it in the eleventh century. Tripurantaka, a manifestation of Lord Shiva, is the temple's principal deity.
